title:
The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency has taken a stunning step—removing references to human causes of climate change and reframing it as “natural variability.” 

This move dismantles decades of… | Benjamin Horton
description:
The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency has taken a stunning step—removing references to human causes of climate change and reframing it as “natural variability.” 

This move dismantles decades of scientific consensus and undermines efforts to curb greenhouse gas emissions.

Meanwhile, here in Asia, we are grappling with an unprecedented series of climate-fueled disasters—typhoons, floods, and landslides that are devastating communities and economies.

Science is clear: human activity drives climate change. Ignoring this reality doesn’t make the problem disappear—it makes it worse.

Now more than ever, global leadership and evidence-based policy are critical.

title: “The Problem with Plastic”: Former EPA Official Judith Enck Discusses New Book
description:
We speak with former EPA regional administrator Judith Enck about her new book, The Problem with Plastic: How We Can Save Ourselves and Our Planet Before It’s Too Late.
“Scientists have found microplastics in our blood, our kidneys, our lungs,” says Enck. “They’ve been found in heart arteries, and if it’s attached to plaque, you have an increased risk of heart attack, stroke, premature death.” Enck says plastic is a “political” issue shaped by the powerful “chemical, fossil fuel, plastics industry — and consumer brands.”
